baseline: Vladimir Lenin posited that "revolutionary syndicalism in many countries was a direct and inevitable result of opportunism, reformism and parliamentary cretinism." A feeling that ideological disputes were draining workers' power led Dutch, French, and American syndicalist organizations to declare themselves independent of any political groups.

prompts: Another common explanation for the rise of syndicalism is that it was
baseline: Another common explanation for the rise of syndicalism is that it was a result of the economic backwardness of the countries in which it emerged, particularly France.

prompts: According to van der Linden and Thorpe , changes in labor processes contributed to the radicalization
baseline: According to van der Linden and Thorpe, changes in labor processes contributed to the radicalization of workers and thereby to the rise of syndicalism.

prompts: Two groups of workers were most attracted to syndicalism :
baseline: Two groups of workers were most attracted to syndicalism: casual or seasonal laborers who frequently changed jobs, and workers whose occupations were becoming obsolete as a result of technological advances.

prompts: Syndicalism came to be seen as a viable strategy because the general strike became a practical possibility
baseline: Syndicalism came to be seen as a viable strategy because the general strike became a practical possibility.

prompts: Finally , van der Linden and Thorpe point to spatial and
baseline: Finally, van der Linden and Thorpe point to spatial and geographical factors that shaped the rise of syndicalism.

prompts: Workers who would otherwise not have had an inclination to
baseline: Workers who would otherwise not have had an inclination to syndicalism joined because syndicalism was dominant in their locales.

prompts: Similarly , southern workers were more drawn to syndicalism in
baseline: Similarly, southern workers were more drawn to syndicalism in Italy.

prompts: According to Altena , the emergence of syndicalism must be analyzed at the level
baseline: According to Altena, the emergence of syndicalism must be analyzed at the level of local communities.

prompts: Syndicalism was not informed by theory or a systematically elaborated ideology the same
baseline: Syndicalism was not informed by theory or a systematically elaborated ideology the same way socialism was by Marxism. Émile Pouget, a CGT leader, maintained: "What sets syndicalism apart from the various schools of socialism –  and makes it superior –  is its doctrinal sobriety.

prompts: Sorel presented himself as the premier theorist of syndicalism and was frequently thought of as such
baseline: Sorel presented himself as the premier theorist of syndicalism and was frequently thought of as such but was not a part of the movement, and his influence on syndicalism was insignificant, except in Italy and Poland.

prompts: Commenting on French syndicalism , the historian Peter Stearns concludes that most workers
baseline: Commenting on French syndicalism, the historian Peter Stearns concludes that most workers did not identify with syndicalism's long-range goals, and that syndicalist hegemony accounts for the relatively slow growth of the French labor movement as a whole.

prompts: Syndicalism was more than a
baseline: Syndicalism was more than a mere tool of a few leaders, and was a genuine product of the French labor movement.

prompts: Syndicalism is used by some interchangeably
baseline: Syndicalism is used by some interchangeably with anarcho-syndicalism.

prompts: Although syndicalism has traditionally been seen as a current within anarchism , it was dominated in some countries
baseline: Although syndicalism has traditionally been seen as a current within anarchism, it was dominated in some countries by Marxists rather than anarchists.

prompts: This was the case in Italy and much of the Anglophone world , including Ireland where anarchists
baseline: This was the case in Italy and much of the Anglophone world, including Ireland where anarchists had no significant influence on syndicalism.

prompts: The anarchist Iain McKay argues that syndicalism is but a new name for ideas and tactics developed by Bakunin and
baseline: The anarchist Iain McKay argues that syndicalism is but a new name for ideas and tactics developed by Bakunin and the anarchist wing of the First International, while it is wholly inconsistent with positions Marx and Engels took.

prompts: According to him , the fact that many Marxists embraced syndicalism merely indicates
baseline: According to him, the fact that many Marxists embraced syndicalism merely indicates that they abandoned Marx's views and converted to Bakunin's.

prompts: Altena too views syndicalism as part of the broader anarchist movement but concedes there was a
baseline: Altena too views syndicalism as part of the broader anarchist movement but concedes there was a tension between this and the fact that it was also a labor movement.

prompts: According to Darlington , anarchism , Marxism , and revolutionary trade unionism equally contributed to syndicalism ,
baseline: According to Darlington, anarchism, Marxism, and revolutionary trade unionism equally contributed to syndicalism, in addition to various influences in specific countries, including Blanquism, anti-clericalism, republicanism, and agrarian radicalism.

prompts: Victor Griffuelhes expressed this at the CGT 's 1906 congress in the following manner : " In its day - to - day demands , syndicalism seeks the co -
baseline: Victor Griffuelhes expressed this at the CGT's 1906 congress in the following manner: "In its day-to-day demands, syndicalism seeks the co-ordination of workers' efforts, the increase of workers' well-being by the achievement of immediate improvements, such as the reduction of working hours, the increase of wages, etc.

prompts: But this task is only one aspect of the work of syndicalism ; it prepares for complete emancipation
baseline: But this task is only one aspect of the work of syndicalism; it prepares for complete emancipation, which can be realised only by expropriating the capitalist class." For unions to fulfill this role, it was necessary to prevent bureaucrats –  "whose sole purpose in life seems to be apologising for and defending the capitalist system of exploitation", according to Larkin –  from inhibiting workers' militant zeal.

prompts: Cover of " Was will der Syndikalismus ? " ( " What does Syndicalism want ? " ) , a pamphlet written by Max Baginski
baseline: Cover of "Was will der Syndikalismus?" ("What does Syndicalism want?"), a pamphlet written by Max Baginski and published by German syndicalists

prompts: Thus , " the IWW 's masculine identity incorporated features of working
baseline: Thus, "the IWW's masculine identity incorporated features of working-class solidarity and protest ... through 'virile' syndicalism." For example, while defending a black fellow worker against a racist insult, an IWW organizer in Louisiana insisted that "he is a man, a union man, an IWW—a MAN! ... and he has proven it by his action." During World War I, one of the IWW's anti-war slogans was "Don't Be a Soldier! Be a Man!" In some cases, syndicalist attitudes towards women changed.

prompts: In Mexico , syndicalism first emerged in 1906 during
baseline: In Mexico, syndicalism first emerged in 1906 during the violent Cananea strike by miners and the even more violent Río Blanco strike by textile workers.

baseline: In 1907, CGT activists presented the Charter of Amiens and syndicalism to an international audience a higher form of anarchism at the International Anarchist Congress of Amsterdam in 1907.

baseline: Delegates did agree on a declaration of principles describing syndicalism's core tenets.

baseline: The UIL's national syndicalism emphasized workers' love of labor, self-sacrifice, and the nation rather than anti-capitalist class struggle.

prompts: The IWW had been nearly destroyed in the previous
baseline: The IWW had been nearly destroyed in the previous two years by local criminal syndicalism laws, the federal government, and vigilante violence.

prompts: The Bolsheviks suppressed syndicalism in Russia but courted syndicalists abroad as
baseline: The Bolsheviks suppressed syndicalism in Russia but courted syndicalists abroad as part of their international strategy.

prompts: The Bolsheviks acknowledged syndicalism 's opposition to socialist reformism and saw them as part
baseline: The Bolsheviks acknowledged syndicalism's opposition to socialist reformism and saw them as part of the revolutionary wing of the labor movement.

baseline: Syndicalism's decline was the result of a number of factors.

baseline: Altena agrees that the state's growing influence in society was decisive for syndicalism's diminished influence.

prompts: Additionally , Altena says that syndicalism lost out to sports
baseline: Additionally, Altena says that syndicalism lost out to sports and entertainment in the cultural sphere.

baseline: Vadim Dam'e adds to this that the development of capitalist production and changes in the division of labor diminished syndicalism's recruitment base.

baseline: According to authors like Stearns, Edward Shorter, Charles Tilly, and Bob Holton, who deem syndicalism a transitional form of workers' resistance between older craft-based artisanship and modern factory-based industry, syndicalism's decline was a product of that transition having been completed and workers being assimilated to capitalist factory discipline.

prompts: Darlington counters that syndicalism attracted a variety of workers , not just artisans and skilled workers ; he concedes that such changes
baseline: Darlington counters that syndicalism attracted a variety of workers, not just artisans and skilled workers; he concedes that such changes played a role in Spain, France, and some other countries.

prompts: Several authors argue that syndicalism 's demise was the result of workers ' inherent pragmatism or conservatism , causing them to only
baseline: Several authors argue that syndicalism's demise was the result of workers' inherent pragmatism or conservatism, causing them to only be interested in immediate material gains rather than long-term goals like overthrowing capitalism.

prompts: Cole do so with respect
baseline: Cole do so with respect to French, Irish, and British syndicalism, respectively.

prompts: According to many Marxists , syndicalism was a reaction to
baseline: According to many Marxists, syndicalism was a reaction to reformism in the labor movement and could not survive without it.

prompts: According to Eric Hobsbawm , the biggest reason for syndicalism 's decline was the rise of
baseline: According to Eric Hobsbawm, the biggest reason for syndicalism's decline was the rise of communism.

prompts: To radical workers , the programmatic distinctions between syndicalism and communism were not all that
baseline: To radical workers, the programmatic distinctions between syndicalism and communism were not all that relevant.

prompts: Darlington also sees the effects of
baseline: Darlington also sees the effects of the Russian Revolution as an important reason for the decline of syndicalism.

prompts: The emergence of communism highlighted syndicalism 's inherent weaknesses : the contradiction of building organizations that sought to be both
baseline: The emergence of communism highlighted syndicalism's inherent weaknesses: the contradiction of building organizations that sought to be both revolutionary cadre organizations and mass labour unions, the emphasis on economic struggle to the detriment of political action and the commitment to localism limiting its ability to provide an effective centralized organization and leadership.

prompts: The Nationalist faction victory in the Spanish Civil War put an end to
baseline: The Nationalist faction victory in the Spanish Civil War put an end to syndicalism as a mass movement.

prompts: Immediately after World War II , there were attempts to rekindle
baseline: Immediately after World War II, there were attempts to rekindle anarcho-syndicalism in Germany; these were thwarted by Cold War anti-communism, Stalinism, and a failure to attract newer younger activists.

prompts: The protest movements of the late 1960s saw renewed interest in
baseline: The protest movements of the late 1960s saw renewed interest in syndicalism by activists in Germany, the United States, and Britain.

prompts: During its Hot Autumn of 1969 , Italy experienced labor actions reminiscent
baseline: During its Hot Autumn of 1969, Italy experienced labor actions reminiscent of syndicalism; according to Carl Levy, syndicalists did not actually exert any influence.

prompts: According to Darlington , syndicalism left a legacy that was widely admired by labor and
baseline: According to Darlington, syndicalism left a legacy that was widely admired by labor and political activists in a number of countries.

prompts: In his study of French syndicalism , Stearns concludes that it was
baseline: In his study of French syndicalism, Stearns concludes that it was a dismal failure.

prompts: Syndicalism was most popular among workers not yet fully integrated into modern capitalist
baseline: Syndicalism was most popular among workers not yet fully integrated into modern capitalist industry but most French workers had adapted to this system and accepted it, therefore it was not able to seriously challenge prevailing conditions or even scare politicians and employers.

prompts: Developed in French labor unions during the late 19th century , syndicalist movements were most predominant amongst
baseline: Developed in French labor unions during the late 19th century, syndicalist movements were most predominant amongst the socialist movement during the interwar period that preceded the outbreak of World War II.

prompts: Major syndicalist organizations included the General Confederation
baseline: Major syndicalist organizations included the General Confederation of Labor (CGT) in France, the Confederacion Nacional del Trabajo (CNT) in Spain, the Italian Syndicalist Union (USI), the Free Workers' Union of Germany (FAUD), and the Argentine Regional Workers' Federation (FORA).

prompts: The Spanish International Workers ' Association – Asociación Internacional de los Trabajadores ( IWA – AIT ) , which was formed in 1922 ,
baseline: The Spanish International Workers' Association – Asociación Internacional de los Trabajadores (IWA–AIT), which was formed in 1922, is an international syndicalist federation of various labour unions from different countries.

prompts: A number of syndicalist organizations were and still are to this day linked in the IWA
baseline: A number of syndicalist organizations were and still are to this day linked in the IWA–AIT; some of its member organizations left for the International Confederation of Labour (ICL–CIT), which was formed in 2018.

prompts: Many scholars , including Ralph Darlington , Marcel van der Linden , and Wayne Thorpe , apply syndicalism to a
baseline: Many scholars, including Ralph Darlington, Marcel van der Linden, and Wayne Thorpe, apply syndicalism to a number of organizations or currents within the labor movement that did not identify as syndicalist.

prompts: The French CGT was the model and
baseline: The French CGT was the model and inspiration for syndicalist groups throughout Europe and the world.

prompts: In a number of countries , certain syndicalist practices and ideas predate the coining of
baseline: In a number of countries, certain syndicalist practices and ideas predate the coining of the term in France or the founding of the IWW.

baseline: In Bert Altena's view, a number of movements in Europe can be called syndicalist, even before 1900.

baseline: Thompson and the anarcho-syndicalist theorist Rudolf Rocker, there were syndicalist tendencies in Britain's labor movement as early as the 1830s.

prompts: He and his followers advocated the general strike , rejected electoral politics ,
baseline: He and his followers advocated the general strike, rejected electoral politics, and anticipated workers' organizations replacing rule by the state, central syndicalist themes.

baseline: According to Lucien van der Walt, the Spanish Regional Federation of the IWA, which was formed in 1870, was in fact syndicalist.

baseline: Although the Wobblies insisted their union was a distinctly American form of labor organization and not an import of European syndicalism, the IWW was syndicalist in the broader sense of the word.

prompts: Syndicalist movements and organizations in a number of countries were established by activists who
baseline: Syndicalist movements and organizations in a number of countries were established by activists who had spent time in France.

baseline: Ervin Szabó visited Paris in 1904 and then established a Syndicalist Propaganda Group in his native Hungary in 1910.

baseline: The IWW's newspapers published articles on French syndicalism, particularly the tactic of sabotage and the CGT's La Vie Ouvrière carried articles about Britain's labor movement by the British syndicalist Tom Mann.

prompts: Foster later abandoned the IWW after a trip to France and set up the Syndicalist
baseline: Foster later abandoned the IWW after a trip to France and set up the Syndicalist League of North America (SLNA), which sought to radicalize the established American Federation of Labor (AFL).

baseline: In Norway, there were both the Norwegian Trade Union Opposition (Norske Fagopposition, NFO), syndicalists working within the mainstream Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions (Landsorganisasjonen i Norge in Norwegian, LO), and the Norwegian Syndicalist Federation (Norsk Syndikalistik Federation in Norwegian, NSF), an independent syndicalist organization set up by the Swedish SAC.

prompts: There was a similar conflict
baseline: There was a similar conflict between the Industrial Syndicalist Education League and the Industrial Workers of Great Britain.

prompts: Employers in France likewise blamed an upsurge in
baseline: Employers in France likewise blamed an upsurge in workers' militancy in the same period on syndicalist leaders.

baseline: Vladimir Lenin posited that "revolutionary syndicalism in many countries was a direct and inevitable result of opportunism, reformism and parliamentary cretinism." A feeling that ideological disputes were draining workers' power led Dutch, French, and American syndicalist organizations to declare themselves independent of any political groups.

prompts: The first group included landless agricultural workers , construction workers , and dockers , all of whom were disproportionately represented in several countries
baseline: The first group included landless agricultural workers, construction workers, and dockers, all of whom were disproportionately represented in several countries' syndicalist movements.

baseline: The small size of many syndicalist unions also makes observations about which workers joined statistically irrelevant.

prompts: Darlington cites the significance of
baseline: Darlington cites the significance of the conscious intervention by syndicalist militants.

baseline: The industrial unrest of the period created conditions which made workers receptive to syndicalist leaders' agitation.

baseline: Only differences in local social and economic structures explain why some towns had a strong syndicalist presence, while others did not.

prompts: Syndicalist thinking was elaborated in pamphlets ,
baseline: Syndicalist thinking was elaborated in pamphlets, leaflets, speeches, and articles and in the movement's own newspapers.

prompts: The philosopher Georges Sorel 's Reflections on Violence introduced syndicalist ideas to
baseline: The philosopher Georges Sorel's Reflections on Violence introduced syndicalist ideas to a broader audience.

prompts: The extent to which syndicalist positions reflected merely the views
baseline: The extent to which syndicalist positions reflected merely the views of leaders and to what extent those positions were shared by syndicalist organizations' rank-and-file is a matter of dispute.

prompts: Commenting on French syndicalism , the historian Peter Stearns concludes that most workers
baseline: Commenting on French syndicalism, the historian Peter Stearns concludes that most workers did not identify with syndicalism's long-range goals, and that syndicalist hegemony accounts for the relatively slow growth of the French labor movement as a whole.

prompts: He says that workers who joined the syndicalist movement were on the whole indifferent to doctrinal questions , their membership in syndicalist organizations was partly accidental , and leaders were unable to convert workers to syndicalist
baseline: He says that workers who joined the syndicalist movement were on the whole indifferent to doctrinal questions, their membership in syndicalist organizations was partly accidental, and leaders were unable to convert workers to syndicalist ideas.

prompts: According to him , leaders were very influential in
baseline: According to him, leaders were very influential in the drafting of syndicalist ideas.

prompts: He also sees Marxist ideas reflected in the movement , as leading syndicalists , such
baseline: He also sees Marxist ideas reflected in the movement, as leading syndicalists, such as Ferdinand Domela Nieuwenhuis and Christiaan Cornelissen, and much of the Australian syndicalist movement were influenced by them, as well as older socialist notions.

prompts: Bill Haywood , an American syndicalist and leading figure in the IWW , defined the union 's
baseline: Bill Haywood, an American syndicalist and leading figure in the IWW, defined the union's purpose at the First Convention of the Industrial Workers of the World as "the emancipation of the working class from the slave bondage of capitalism".

prompts: Tom Mann , a British syndicalist , declared that " the
baseline: Tom Mann, a British syndicalist, declared that "the object of the unions is to wage the Class War".

prompts: According to syndicalist doctrine , this war was aimed not just at
baseline: According to syndicalist doctrine, this war was aimed not just at gaining concessions such as higher wages or a shorter working day but at the revolutionary overthrow of capitalism.

prompts: Nevertheless , a number of leading syndicalist figures worked in political parties
baseline: Nevertheless, a number of leading syndicalist figures worked in political parties and some ran for elected office.

prompts: According to Thomas Hagerty , a Catholic priest and IWW leader , " dropping pieces of paper
baseline: According to Thomas Hagerty, a Catholic priest and IWW leader, "dropping pieces of paper into a hole in a box never did achieve emancipation for the working class, and to my thinking it will never achieve it." Syndicalist trade unions declared their political neutrality and autonomy from political parties.

prompts: The French syndicalist Pouget explained : " The CGT embraces   –
baseline: The French syndicalist Pouget explained: "The CGT embraces –  outside of all the schools of politics –  all workers cognisant of the struggle to be waged for the elimination of wage-slavery and the employer class." In practice, this neutrality was more ambiguous.

prompts: In the syndicalist conception , unions played a dual role
baseline: In the syndicalist conception, unions played a dual role.

prompts: Similarly , syndicalist unions did not work to build large
baseline: Similarly, syndicalist unions did not work to build large strike funds, for fear that they would create bureaucracy separate from the rank-and-file and instill in workers the expectation that the union rather than they would wage the class struggle.

prompts: Thus , " the IWW 's masculine identity incorporated features of working
baseline: Thus, "the IWW's masculine identity incorporated features of working-class solidarity and protest ... through 'virile' syndicalism." For example, while defending a black fellow worker against a racist insult, an IWW organizer in Louisiana insisted that "he is a man, a union man, an IWW—a MAN! ... and he has proven it by his action." During World War I, one of the IWW's anti-war slogans was "Don't Be a Soldier! Be a Man!" In some cases, syndicalist attitudes towards women changed.

prompts: According to the historian Sharif Gemie , the male orientation of parts of the syndicalist labor movement reflected the ideas of
baseline: According to the historian Sharif Gemie, the male orientation of parts of the syndicalist labor movement reflected the ideas of the anarchist Pierre-Joseph Proudhon, who defended patriarchy because women, of their own accord, are "chained to nature".

prompts: In 1912 , during the Mexican Revolution of 1910–1920 , anarchists formed the syndicalist union
baseline: In 1912, during the Mexican Revolution of 1910–1920, anarchists formed the syndicalist union House of the World Worker (Casa del Obrero Mundial).

prompts: The syndicalist union confederation USI was formed in 1912 by
baseline: The syndicalist union confederation USI was formed in 1912 by veterans of both strike movements.

prompts: A session of the First
baseline: A session of the First International Syndicalist Congress in 1913

prompts: There was no international syndicalist
baseline: There was no international syndicalist organization prior to World War I.

prompts: Discussions at the Congress led to the formation
baseline: Discussions at the Congress led to the formation of the international syndicalist journal Bulletin international du mouvement syndicaliste.

prompts: Both the Dutch NAS and the British ISEL attempted to remedy the
baseline: Both the Dutch NAS and the British ISEL attempted to remedy the lack of a syndicalist counterpart to ISNTUC in 1913, simultaneously publishing calls for an international syndicalist congress in 1913.

prompts: The First International Syndicalist Congress was held in London from
baseline: The First International Syndicalist Congress was held in London from 27 September to 2 October.

prompts: Discussions were contentious and did not lead to the founding
baseline: Discussions were contentious and did not lead to the founding of a syndicalist international.

prompts: They also decided to launch an International Syndicalist Information Bureau and to hold another congress in
baseline: They also decided to launch an International Syndicalist Information Bureau and to hold another congress in Amsterdam.

prompts: Moreover , a number of anarchists led by Peter Kropotkin
baseline: Moreover, a number of anarchists led by Peter Kropotkin, including the influential syndicalist Christiaan Cornelissen, issued the Manifesto of the Sixteen, supporting the Allied cause in the war.

prompts: As a result , according to historians like Darlington or van der Linden and Thorpe , the CGT was no longer a
baseline: As a result, according to historians like Darlington or van der Linden and Thorpe, the CGT was no longer a revolutionary syndicalist organization after the start of World War I.

prompts: From the start of the war , even before Italy did so , a
baseline: From the start of the war, even before Italy did so, a minority within USI, led by the most famous Italian syndicalist, Alceste De Ambris, called on the Italian state to take the Allies' side.

prompts: August 1914 edition of Die Einigkeit , a German syndicalist newspaper , protesting the outbreak of
baseline: August 1914 edition of Die Einigkeit, a German syndicalist newspaper, protesting the outbreak of war

prompts: Although the congress was poorly planned and prohibited by the Spanish
baseline: Although the congress was poorly planned and prohibited by the Spanish authorities, delegates managed to discuss resistance to the war and extending international cooperation between syndicalist groups.

prompts: German , Swedish , Dutch , and Spanish syndicalists denounced nationalism with Tierra
baseline: German, Swedish, Dutch, and Spanish syndicalists denounced nationalism with Tierra y Libertad, a syndicalist journal in Barcelona, calling it a "grotesque mentality".

prompts: Thanks in part to their fidelity to internationalism , syndicalist organizations profited from this
baseline: Thanks in part to their fidelity to internationalism, syndicalist organizations profited from this development and expanded as the war drew to an end.

prompts: Russian syndicalists organized around the journal Golos Truda ( The Voice of Labor ) , which had a circulation of
baseline: Russian syndicalists organized around the journal Golos Truda (The Voice of Labor), which had a circulation of around 25,000, and the Union of Anarcho-Syndicalist Propaganda.

prompts: The syndicalists viewed the factory committees
baseline: The syndicalists viewed the factory committees as the true form of syndicalist organization, not unions.

prompts: The Petrograd Soviet established the 66 - member Petrograd Military Revolutionary Committee , which included four anarchists ,
baseline: The Petrograd Soviet established the 66-member Petrograd Military Revolutionary Committee, which included four anarchists, among them the syndicalist Shatov.

prompts: The government reacted by having anarchists throughout the country arrested , including a
baseline: The government reacted by having anarchists throughout the country arrested, including a number of syndicalist leaders.

prompts: Augustin Souchy , a German anarcho - syndicalist , hailed it " the
baseline: Augustin Souchy, a German anarcho-syndicalist, hailed it "the great passion that swept us all along.

prompts: The syndicalist FVdG , which had just 6,000 members before the war and was almost completely suppressed by the state
baseline: The syndicalist FVdG, which had just 6,000 members before the war and was almost completely suppressed by the state during the war, regrouped at a conference in Berlin in December 1918.

prompts: The 1918 Portugal general strike was called for November but
baseline: The 1918 Portugal general strike was called for November but failed, and in 1919 the syndicalist General Confederation of Labour (Confederação Geral do Trabalho, CGT) was formed as the country's first national union confederation.

prompts: In Argentina , FORA had split into the anarcho
baseline: In Argentina, FORA had split into the anarcho-communist FORA V and the syndicalist FORA IX.

prompts: They formed the Revolutionary Syndicalist Committees and attempted to push the
baseline: They formed the Revolutionary Syndicalist Committees and attempted to push the CGT as a whole to support the Comintern.

prompts: Instead , the congress revealed the irreconcilable differences
baseline: Instead, the congress revealed the irreconcilable differences between the syndicalist and the Bolshevik approach.

prompts: A document proposed by Solomon Lozovsky derided the apolitical unions
baseline: A document proposed by Solomon Lozovsky derided the apolitical unions as "lackeys of imperialist capitalism" for their betrayal during the war, to which syndicalists replied that of the syndicalist unions this only applied to the CGT.

prompts: From the early 1920s , the traditional syndicalist movements in most countries began to wane ;
baseline: From the early 1920s, the traditional syndicalist movements in most countries began to wane; state repression played a role, although movements that were not suppressed also declined.

prompts: According to van der Linden and Thorpe , syndicalist organizations saw themselves as having
baseline: According to van der Linden and Thorpe, syndicalist organizations saw themselves as having three options: they could stay true to their revolutionary principles and be marginalized, they could give up those principles in order to adapt to new conditions, or they could disband or merge into non-syndicalist organizations.

prompts: The Spanish Revolution of 1936 resulted in the widespread
baseline: The Spanish Revolution of 1936 resulted in the widespread implementation of anarcho-syndicalist and more broadly socialist organizational principles throughout various portions of the country for two to three years, primarily Catalonia, Aragon, Andalusia, and parts of the Levante, with the main union organization of the Republican faction being the CNT.

prompts: By the end of the 1930s , meaningful legal syndicalist organizations existed only in Bolivia
baseline: By the end of the 1930s, meaningful legal syndicalist organizations existed only in Bolivia, Chile, Sweden and Uruguay.

prompts: In Russia , Italy , Portugal , Germany , Spain , and the Netherlands , syndicalist movements were suppressed by authoritarian governments
baseline: In Russia, Italy, Portugal, Germany, Spain, and the Netherlands, syndicalist movements were suppressed by authoritarian governments.

prompts: Bolshevism 's overcoming of these limitations and its success in Russia drew syndicalist leaders and
baseline: Bolshevism's overcoming of these limitations and its success in Russia drew syndicalist leaders and members.

prompts: It also exacerbated splits within the
baseline: It also exacerbated splits within the syndicalist camp.

prompts: During the 1980s in the Polish People 's Republic , the trade union Solidarity ( Solidarność ) , even though not strictly syndicalist , attracted masses of dissident
baseline: During the 1980s in the Polish People's Republic, the trade union Solidarity (Solidarność), even though not strictly syndicalist, attracted masses of dissident workers by reviving many syndicalist ideas and practices.

prompts: Among its member organizations is the British Solidarity Federation , which was formed in 1950 ,

baseline: Drawing from the theory of libertarian socialism and the practice of syndicalism, anarcho-syndicalism sees trade unions as both a means to achieve immediate improvements to working conditions and to build towards a social revolution in the form of a general strike, with the ultimate aim of abolishing the state and capitalism.

baseline: An anti-political ideology, anarcho-syndicalism rejects political parties and participation in parliamentary politics, considering them to be a corrupting influence on the labour movement.

baseline: Anarcho-syndicalism was constituted as a specific tendency following the International Anarchist Congress of Amsterdam, which led to anarcho-syndicalism becoming the dominant form of trade union organisation in Europe and Latin America.

baseline: Anarcho-syndicalism reached its apex during the Spanish Revolution of 1936, when the National Confederation of Labour (CNT) established an anarcho-syndicalist economy throughout much of the Spanish Republic.

baseline: The history of anarcho-syndicalism can be traced back to the anarchist faction of the International Workingmen's Association (IWA), which called for trade unions to overthrow the state in a general strike.

baseline: But tensions between rank-and-file trade unionists and their social-democratic leadership eventually gave way to the development of revolutionary syndicalism, which called for workers themselves to take direct action in order to improve their own material conditions.

baseline: Revolutionary syndicalism was first propagated in France, where the Bourses du Travail (English: Labour Exchanges) were established to provide mutual aid to workers and organise strike actions.

baseline: However, by this time, revolutionary syndicalism had already spread throughout Europe, with syndicalist unions being established in the Netherlands, Italy, Portugal , Germany and Sweden.

baseline: Anarcho-syndicalism soon became the dominant form of trade union organisation in Spain, Argentina, Brazil, Mexico, Paraguay, Uruguay and many other Latin American countries, where anarcho-syndicalists organised a series of general strikes for the eight-hour day.

baseline: By the turn of the 21st century, anarcho-syndicalism had experienced a resurgence, as anarcho-syndicalist organisations re-emerged throughout the globe.

prompts: The political theory of anarcho - syndicalism is based on the foundations
baseline: The political theory of anarcho-syndicalism is based on the foundations of libertarian socialism, as formulated by the anti-authoritarian faction of the International Workingmen's Association, while its organisational forms were adopted from revolutionary syndicalism, which was first put into practice by the French labour movement in the early 20th century.

prompts: Anarcho - syndicalism is distinguished from other forms of syndicalism by its anarchist political philosophy , where other syndicalist tendencies distance themselves from anarchism
baseline: Anarcho-syndicalism is distinguished from other forms of syndicalism by its anarchist political philosophy, where other syndicalist tendencies distance themselves from anarchism or even deny any political alignment.

baseline: Other varieties of syndicalism include: the "neutral" revolutionary syndicalism, which separates itself from other political theories; Daniel De Leon's conception of industrial unionism, which infused it with a Marxist influence; and an authoritarian form of syndicalism developed by Georges Sorel, which advocates for vanguardism and mythmaking to drive the masses towards a general strike.

prompts: Anarcho - syndicalism also distinguishes itself from other
baseline: Anarcho-syndicalism also distinguishes itself from other forms of anarchism, due to its favourability towards industrialisation and organisation.

prompts: While other forms of anarchism reject economic centralisation and the division of labour , considering the ideal of
baseline: While other forms of anarchism reject economic centralisation and the division of labour, considering the ideal of a stateless society to be one of decentralised, small-scale social units, anarcho-syndicalism foresees trade unions as taking over a large-scale and centralised industrial economy.

prompts: In the contemporary period , anarcho - syndicalism is divided into two main
baseline: In the contemporary period, anarcho-syndicalism is divided into two main factions: the "orthodox" faction, which rejects any diversity of tactics or collaboration with statist forces, in favour of waiting for the right conditions for a revolutionary situation; and the "revisionist" faction, which is open to participation in systems of social welfare and pursues gradual reforms towards the democratisation of the economy.

prompts: Anarcho - syndicalism is an apolitical or anti - political ideology , opposed to the formation
baseline: Anarcho-syndicalism is an apolitical or anti-political ideology, opposed to the formation of socialist political parties and participation in parliamentary politics.

prompts: Workers ' education is therefore at the centre of anarcho - syndicalism , which aims to use trade
baseline: Workers' education is therefore at the centre of anarcho-syndicalism, which aims to use trade unions to prepare workers to take over management of the industrial economy.

prompts: Outline of the federal system used by anarcho -
baseline: Outline of the federal system used by anarcho-syndicalism

prompts: Anarcho - syndicalism also seeks to abolish capitalism and replace
baseline: Anarcho-syndicalism also seeks to abolish capitalism and replace it with socialism, which it does by lowering the profit margins of business owners and raising the workers' share in the product of their own labour.

prompts: Anarcho - syndicalism is driven by the practice of direct action , which eschews legalistic methods in
baseline: Anarcho-syndicalism is driven by the practice of direct action, which eschews legalistic methods in favour of workers forcing their employers to make concessions.

baseline: Anarcho-syndicalism reached its apex during the Spanish Revolution of 1936, when the National Confederation of Labour (CNT) established an anarcho-syndicalist economy throughout much of the Spanish Republic.

baseline: The movement split into two factions: the "orthodox" faction, which held to traditional syndicalist principles in spite of changing material conditions; and the "revisionist" faction, which aimed to achieve a mass base and work within the framework of newly-established welfare states.

baseline: By the end of the 20th century, the rise of neoliberalism and the collapse of the Eastern Bloc had led to a revival in anarcho-syndicalism, with syndicalist unions once again being established throughout the globe.

baseline: However, by this time, revolutionary syndicalism had already spread throughout Europe, with syndicalist unions being established in the Netherlands, Italy, Portugal , Germany and Sweden.

baseline: Although anarchists widely participated in the syndicalist movement, syndicalists were divided into separate tendencies, many of which rejected the ideological prescriptions of anarchism.

baseline: At the International Anarchist Congress of Amsterdam, convened by the anarcho-syndicalist Christiaan Cornelissen in 1907, a conflict between the two tendencies broke out; while the syndicalist Pierre Monatte and the anarchist Errico Malatesta debated their respective ideologies, Amédée Dunois attempted to synthesise the two into a "workers' anarchism".

prompts: Attempts to establish international links between these anarcho - syndicalist organisations culminated in the convocation
baseline: Attempts to establish international links between these anarcho-syndicalist organisations culminated in the convocation of a revolutionary syndicalist congress in 1913, although further movements towards the creation of an international organisation were halted by the outbreak of world war.

baseline: With the outbreak of the Spanish Civil War, the CNT led the defeat of the Nationalists in Catalonia, where they ignited an anarcho-syndicalist revolution that collectivised three-quarters of the Republican economy.

prompts: After the war , anarcho - syndicalism experienced a rapid decline
baseline: After the war, anarcho-syndicalism experienced a rapid decline, as anarcho-syndicalist unions were either marginalised by rising social corporatism or repressed by newly-established authoritarian states.

baseline: Anarcho-syndicalists proved unable to keep up with the changes in the post-war capitalist system, which hastened the decline of the anarcho-syndicalist movement and forced its organisations to choose between marginalisation, reform or dissolution.

prompts: Despite the economic changes , the IWA chose to reaffirm traditional
baseline: Despite the economic changes, the IWA chose to reaffirm traditional anarcho-syndicalist principles, causing its Dutch and Swedish sections to split from it.

baseline: The anarcho-syndicalist movement began to experience a revival in the wake of the protests of 1968 and the Spanish transition to democracy.

baseline: By the turn of the 21st century, anarcho-syndicalism had experienced a resurgence, as anarcho-syndicalist organisations re-emerged throughout the globe.

baseline: Existing anarcho-syndicalist unions once again began taking direct action and organising strikes, while new anarcho-syndicalist unions established large support bases and achieved social reforms.

baseline: Anarcho-syndicalism is distinguished from other forms of syndicalism by its anarchist political philosophy, where other syndicalist tendencies distance themselves from anarchism or even deny any political alignment.

baseline: Anarcho-syndicalists believe that the establishment of a syndicalist system could lead to the withering away of the state and as such to anarchy and communism.

prompts: For anarcho - syndicalists , trade unions represent the prefiguration of
baseline: For anarcho-syndicalists, trade unions represent the prefiguration of a future socialist economy, the foundation that a new syndicalist society will be built on.

prompts: In anarcho - syndicalist organisations , individual unions carry out their activities
baseline: In anarcho-syndicalist organisations, individual unions carry out their activities on a voluntary basis; for any larger-scale activity that requires delegation, representatives are typically elected for single terms and are paid the same amount as the workers they represent.

prompts: According to the anarcho - syndicalist model , federal organisations are built from the bottom
baseline: According to the anarcho-syndicalist model, federal organisations are built from the bottom-up, on both a territorial and industrial basis: first, workers join together in independent trade unions; the trade unions in a given city or district then combine into a cartel, which act as centres for popular education and build solidarity between workers of different trades; the cartels then group together on a regional basis, up to the national level, providing larger-scale coordination between its member organisations.

prompts: National syndicalism is a far - right adaptation of syndicalism to suit the broader agenda
baseline: National syndicalism is a far-right adaptation of syndicalism to suit the broader agenda of integral nationalism.

baseline: National syndicalism developed in France in the early 20th century, and then spread to Italy, Spain, and Portugal.

baseline: French national syndicalism was an adaptation of Georges Sorel's version of revolutionary syndicalism to the monarchist ideology of integral nationalism, as practised by Action Française.

prompts: Georges Sorel is sometimes described as the father
baseline: Georges Sorel is sometimes described as the father of revolutionary syndicalism.

baseline: The intention of syndicalism was to organize strikes to abolish capitalism; not to supplant it with State socialism, but rather to build a society of worker-class producers.

baseline: Maurras favorably mentioned Sorel and revolutionary syndicalism in the book, and even sent a copy of the new edition to Sorel.

baseline: Three months later, on 10 July, Sorel published in Il Divenire sociale (the leading journal of Italian revolutionary syndicalism) an essay admiring Maurras and Action Française.

prompts: Benito Mussolini declared in 1909 that he had converted over to revolutionary
baseline: Benito Mussolini declared in 1909 that he had converted over to revolutionary syndicalism by 1904 during a general strike.

baseline: Enrico Corradini promoted a form of national syndicalism that utilized Maurassian nationalism alongside the syndicalism of Georges Sorel.

baseline: A number of Italian fascist leaders began to _relabel national syndicalism as Fascist syndicalism.

prompts: Mussolini was one of the first to disseminate this term ,
baseline: Mussolini was one of the first to disseminate this term, explaining that "Fascist syndicalism is national and productivistic… in a national society in which labor becomes a joy, an object of pride and a title to nobility." By the time Edmondo Rossoni became secretary-general of the General Confederation of Fascist Syndical Corporations in December 1922, other Italian national syndicalists were adopting the "Fascist syndicalism" phrase in their aim at "building and reorganizing political structures… through a synthesis of State and labor".

baseline: In November 1918, Mussolini defined national syndicalism as a doctrine that would unite economic classes into a program of national development and growth.

baseline: National syndicalism in the Iberian Peninsula is a political theory very similar to the Fascist idea of corporatism, inspired by Integralism and the Action Française (for a French parallel, see Cercle Proudhon).

prompts: National syndicalism under Franco aimed to provide a suitable replacement
baseline: National syndicalism under Franco aimed to provide a suitable replacement for capitalist mode of production with worker managed cooperatives, a system in which workers and employers elect representatives to form syndicates/corporations which manage worker and employer relationships and instantiating and promulgate worker ownership.

prompts: National syndicalism was intended to win over
baseline: National syndicalism was intended to win over the anarcho-syndicalist Confederación Nacional del Trabajo (CNT) to a corporatist nationalism.

prompts: National syndicalism was one of the
baseline: National syndicalism was one of the ideological bases of Francoist Spain, especially in the early years.

baseline: It included Berth, Valois, Lagrange, the syndicalist Albert Vincent and the royalists Gilbert Maire, René de Marans, André Pascalon, and Marius Riquier.

baseline: From 1902 to 1910, a number of Italian revolutionary syndicalists including Arturo Labriola, Agostino Lanzillo, Angelo Oliviero Olivetti, Alceste De Ambris, Filippo Corridoni and Sergio Panunzio sought to unify the Italian nationalist cause with the syndicalist cause and had entered into contact with Italian nationalist figures such as Enrico Corradini.

prompts: Not all Italian revolutionary syndicalists joined the Fascist cause , but most syndicalist leaders eventually embraced nationalism and "
baseline: Not all Italian revolutionary syndicalists joined the Fascist cause, but most syndicalist leaders eventually embraced nationalism and "were among the founders of the Fascist movement," where "many even held key posts" in Mussolini's regime.

baseline: Corradini spoke of the need for a national syndicalist movement that would be able to solve Italy's problems, led by elitist aristocrats and anti-democrats who shared a revolutionary syndicalist commitment to direct action through a willingness to fight.

baseline: Seen at the time as "radical or leftist elements," Rossoni and his syndicalist cadre had "served to some extent to protect the immediate economic interests of the workers and to preserve their class consciousness".

prompts: National syndicalism was intended to win over
baseline: National syndicalism was intended to win over the anarcho-syndicalist Confederación Nacional del Trabajo (CNT) to a corporatist nationalism.

prompts: However , the National Syndicalist movement effectively emerged as a separate
baseline: However, the National Syndicalist movement effectively emerged as a separate political tendency.

baseline: Franco introduced in 1940 a radical syndicalist law that gave extensive rights to workers in the syndicates.

baseline: In later years the rights of the syndicates became more constrained, but there are still examples of successful worker cooperatives such as the Mondragon worker cooperative that could develop under the wings of Franco’s national syndicalist regime.

baseline: The Unidad Falangista Montañesa maintained a trade union wing, called the Association of National-Syndicalist Workers.

baseline: Syndicalism is a revolutionary current within the labour movement that, through industrial unionism, seeks to unionize workers according to industry and advance their demands through strikes, with the eventual goal of gaining control over the means of production and the economy at large through social ownership.

prompts: The concept of syndicalisme révolutionnaire or revolutionary syndicalism emerged in French socialist
baseline: The concept of syndicalisme révolutionnaire or revolutionary syndicalism emerged in French socialist journals in 1903, and the French General Confederation of Labor (Confédération générale du travail, CGT) came to use the term to describe its brand of unionism.

prompts: Revolutionary syndicalism , or more commonly syndicalism with the revolutionary implied , was then
baseline: Revolutionary syndicalism, or more commonly syndicalism with the revolutionary implied, was then adapted to a number of languages by unionists following the French model.

baseline: Many scholars, including Ralph Darlington, Marcel van der Linden, and Wayne Thorpe, apply syndicalism to a number of organizations or currents within the labor movement that did not identify as syndicalist.

baseline: Van der Linden and Thorpe use syndicalism to refer to "all revolutionary, direct-actionist organizations".

baseline: Darlington proposes that syndicalism be defined as "revolutionary trade unionism".

baseline: Syndicalism originated in France and spread from there.

baseline: Revolutionary industrial unionism, part of syndicalism in the broader sense, originated with the IWW in the United States and then caught on in other countries.

baseline: Syndicalism's direct roots were in Pierre Joseph Proudhon's mutualism, a form of socialism that focused on cooperation among the community of man.

baseline: Kenyon Zimmer sees a "proto-syndicalism" in the influence the anarchist-led International Working People's Association (IWPA) and Central Labor Union, which originated in the American section of the First International, had in the Chicago labor movement of the 1880s.

baseline: Although the Wobblies insisted their union was a distinctly American form of labor organization and not an import of European syndicalism, the IWW was syndicalist in the broader sense of the word.

baseline: According to Melvyn Dubofsky and most other IWW historians, the IWW's industrial unionism was the specifically American form of syndicalism.

prompts: French syndicalism and American industrial unionism influenced the rise of
baseline: French syndicalism and American industrial unionism influenced the rise of syndicalism elsewhere.

baseline: The IWW's newspapers published articles on French syndicalism, particularly the tactic of sabotage and the CGT's La Vie Ouvrière carried articles about Britain's labor movement by the British syndicalist Tom Mann.

prompts: International work processes also contributed to the diffusion
baseline: International work processes also contributed to the diffusion of syndicalism.

baseline: There were also groups advocating syndicalism in Russia, Japan, the United States, Portugal, Norway, Denmark, Hungary, and Great Britain.

baseline: In Ireland, syndicalism took the form of the Irish Transport and General Workers' Union (ITGWU), which espoused a mix of industrial unionism and socialist Irish republicanism, and was labeled Larkinism.

baseline: According to van der Linden and Thorpe, syndicalism was only one way this radicalization expressed itself.

baseline: While many historians see syndicalism as a consequence of this unrest, Elie Halévy and the politician Lord Robert Cecil argue it was its cause.

baseline: Syndicalism was further encouraged by employers' hostility to workers' actions.

baseline: Vladimir Lenin posited that "revolutionary syndicalism in many countries was a direct and inevitable result of opportunism, reformism and parliamentary cretinism." A feeling that ideological disputes were draining workers' power led Dutch, French, and American syndicalist organizations to declare themselves independent of any political groups.

prompts: Another common explanation for the rise of syndicalism is that it was
baseline: Another common explanation for the rise of syndicalism is that it was a result of the economic backwardness of the countries in which it emerged, particularly France.

baseline: According to van der Linden and Thorpe, changes in labor processes contributed to the radicalization of workers and thereby to the rise of syndicalism.

prompts: Two groups of workers were most attracted to syndicalism :
baseline: Two groups of workers were most attracted to syndicalism: casual or seasonal laborers who frequently changed jobs, and workers whose occupations were becoming obsolete as a result of technological advances.

prompts: Syndicalism came to be seen as a viable strategy because the general strike became a practical possibility
baseline: Syndicalism came to be seen as a viable strategy because the general strike became a practical possibility.

prompts: Finally , van der Linden and Thorpe point to spatial and
baseline: Finally, van der Linden and Thorpe point to spatial and geographical factors that shaped the rise of syndicalism.

prompts: Workers who would otherwise not have had an inclination to
baseline: Workers who would otherwise not have had an inclination to syndicalism joined because syndicalism was dominant in their locales.

prompts: Similarly , southern workers were more drawn to syndicalism in
baseline: Similarly, southern workers were more drawn to syndicalism in Italy.

prompts: According to Altena , the emergence of syndicalism must be analyzed at the level
baseline: According to Altena, the emergence of syndicalism must be analyzed at the level of local communities.

prompts: Syndicalism was not informed by theory or a systematically elaborated ideology the same
baseline: Syndicalism was not informed by theory or a systematically elaborated ideology the same way socialism was by Marxism. Émile Pouget, a CGT leader, maintained: "What sets syndicalism apart from the various schools of socialism –  and makes it superior –  is its doctrinal sobriety.

prompts: Sorel presented himself as the premier theorist of syndicalism and was frequently thought of as such
baseline: Sorel presented himself as the premier theorist of syndicalism and was frequently thought of as such but was not a part of the movement, and his influence on syndicalism was insignificant, except in Italy and Poland.

prompts: Commenting on French syndicalism , the historian Peter Stearns concludes that most workers
baseline: Commenting on French syndicalism, the historian Peter Stearns concludes that most workers did not identify with syndicalism's long-range goals, and that syndicalist hegemony accounts for the relatively slow growth of the French labor movement as a whole.

prompts: Syndicalism was more than a
baseline: Syndicalism was more than a mere tool of a few leaders, and was a genuine product of the French labor movement.

prompts: Syndicalism is used by some interchangeably
baseline: Syndicalism is used by some interchangeably with anarcho-syndicalism.

prompts: Although syndicalism has traditionally been seen as a current within anarchism , it was dominated in some countries
baseline: Although syndicalism has traditionally been seen as a current within anarchism, it was dominated in some countries by Marxists rather than anarchists.

baseline: The anarchist Iain McKay argues that syndicalism is but a new name for ideas and tactics developed by Bakunin and the anarchist wing of the First International, while it is wholly inconsistent with positions Marx and Engels took.

baseline: Altena too views syndicalism as part of the broader anarchist movement but concedes there was a tension between this and the fact that it was also a labor movement.

baseline: According to Darlington, anarchism, Marxism, and revolutionary trade unionism equally contributed to syndicalism, in addition to various influences in specific countries, including Blanquism, anti-clericalism, republicanism, and agrarian radicalism.

prompts: Victor Griffuelhes expressed this at the CGT 's 1906 congress in the following manner : " In its day - to - day demands , syndicalism seeks the co -
baseline: Victor Griffuelhes expressed this at the CGT's 1906 congress in the following manner: "In its day-to-day demands, syndicalism seeks the co-ordination of workers' efforts, the increase of workers' well-being by the achievement of immediate improvements, such as the reduction of working hours, the increase of wages, etc.

prompts: But this task is only one aspect of the work of syndicalism ; it prepares for complete emancipation
baseline: But this task is only one aspect of the work of syndicalism; it prepares for complete emancipation, which can be realised only by expropriating the capitalist class." For unions to fulfill this role, it was necessary to prevent bureaucrats –  "whose sole purpose in life seems to be apologising for and defending the capitalist system of exploitation", according to Larkin –  from inhibiting workers' militant zeal.

prompts: Cover of " Was will der Syndikalismus ? " ( " What does Syndicalism want ? " ) , a pamphlet written by Max Baginski
baseline: Cover of "Was will der Syndikalismus?" ("What does Syndicalism want?"), a pamphlet written by Max Baginski and published by German syndicalists

prompts: Thus , " the IWW 's masculine identity incorporated features of working
baseline: Thus, "the IWW's masculine identity incorporated features of working-class solidarity and protest ... through 'virile' syndicalism." For example, while defending a black fellow worker against a racist insult, an IWW organizer in Louisiana insisted that "he is a man, a union man, an IWW—a MAN! ... and he has proven it by his action." During World War I, one of the IWW's anti-war slogans was "Don't Be a Soldier! Be a Man!" In some cases, syndicalist attitudes towards women changed.

baseline: The IWW had been nearly destroyed in the previous two years by local criminal syndicalism laws, the federal government, and vigilante violence.

baseline: The Bolsheviks suppressed syndicalism in Russia but courted syndicalists abroad as part of their international strategy.

baseline: The Bolsheviks acknowledged syndicalism's opposition to socialist reformism and saw them as part of the revolutionary wing of the labor movement.

baseline: Altena agrees that the state's growing influence in society was decisive for syndicalism's diminished influence.

baseline: According to authors like Stearns, Edward Shorter, Charles Tilly, and Bob Holton, who deem syndicalism a transitional form of workers' resistance between older craft-based artisanship and modern factory-based industry, syndicalism's decline was a product of that transition having been completed and workers being assimilated to capitalist factory discipline.

baseline: Darlington counters that syndicalism attracted a variety of workers, not just artisans and skilled workers; he concedes that such changes played a role in Spain, France, and some other countries.

baseline: Cole do so with respect to French, Irish, and British syndicalism, respectively.

baseline: According to many Marxists, syndicalism was a reaction to reformism in the labor movement and could not survive without it.

baseline: According to Eric Hobsbawm, the biggest reason for syndicalism's decline was the rise of communism.

baseline: To radical workers, the programmatic distinctions between syndicalism and communism were not all that relevant.

baseline: The emergence of communism highlighted syndicalism's inherent weaknesses: the contradiction of building organizations that sought to be both revolutionary cadre organizations and mass labour unions, the emphasis on economic struggle to the detriment of political action and the commitment to localism limiting its ability to provide an effective centralized organization and leadership.

baseline: The protest movements of the late 1960s saw renewed interest in syndicalism by activists in Germany, the United States, and Britain.

baseline: During its Hot Autumn of 1969, Italy experienced labor actions reminiscent of syndicalism; according to Carl Levy, syndicalists did not actually exert any influence.

baseline: According to Darlington, syndicalism left a legacy that was widely admired by labor and political activists in a number of countries.

baseline: In his study of French syndicalism, Stearns concludes that it was a dismal failure.

baseline: Syndicalism was most popular among workers not yet fully integrated into modern capitalist industry but most French workers had adapted to this system and accepted it, therefore it was not able to seriously challenge prevailing conditions or even scare politicians and employers.

baseline: Developed in French labor unions during the late 19th century, syndicalist movements were most predominant amongst the socialist movement during the interwar period that preceded the outbreak of World War II.

baseline: Major syndicalist organizations included the General Confederation of Labor (CGT) in France, the Confederacion Nacional del Trabajo (CNT) in Spain, the Italian Syndicalist Union (USI), the Free Workers' Union of Germany (FAUD), and the Argentine Regional Workers' Federation (FORA).

baseline: The Spanish International Workers' Association – Asociación Internacional de los Trabajadores (IWA–AIT), which was formed in 1922, is an international syndicalist federation of various labour unions from different countries.

baseline: A number of syndicalist organizations were and still are to this day linked in the IWA–AIT; some of its member organizations left for the International Confederation of Labour (ICL–CIT), which was formed in 2018.

baseline: Many scholars, including Ralph Darlington, Marcel van der Linden, and Wayne Thorpe, apply syndicalism to a number of organizations or currents within the labor movement that did not identify as syndicalist.

baseline: In Bert Altena's view, a number of movements in Europe can be called syndicalist, even before 1900.

baseline: Thompson and the anarcho-syndicalist theorist Rudolf Rocker, there were syndicalist tendencies in Britain's labor movement as early as the 1830s.

baseline: Ervin Szabó visited Paris in 1904 and then established a Syndicalist Propaganda Group in his native Hungary in 1910.

baseline: The IWW's newspapers published articles on French syndicalism, particularly the tactic of sabotage and the CGT's La Vie Ouvrière carried articles about Britain's labor movement by the British syndicalist Tom Mann.

baseline: Foster later abandoned the IWW after a trip to France and set up the Syndicalist League of North America (SLNA), which sought to radicalize the established American Federation of Labor (AFL).

baseline: There was a similar conflict between the Industrial Syndicalist Education League and the Industrial Workers of Great Britain.

baseline: Vladimir Lenin posited that "revolutionary syndicalism in many countries was a direct and inevitable result of opportunism, reformism and parliamentary cretinism." A feeling that ideological disputes were draining workers' power led Dutch, French, and American syndicalist organizations to declare themselves independent of any political groups.

baseline: The first group included landless agricultural workers, construction workers, and dockers, all of whom were disproportionately represented in several countries' syndicalist movements.

baseline: Only differences in local social and economic structures explain why some towns had a strong syndicalist presence, while others did not.

baseline: The philosopher Georges Sorel's Reflections on Violence introduced syndicalist ideas to a broader audience.

baseline: The extent to which syndicalist positions reflected merely the views of leaders and to what extent those positions were shared by syndicalist organizations' rank-and-file is a matter of dispute.

baseline: Commenting on French syndicalism, the historian Peter Stearns concludes that most workers did not identify with syndicalism's long-range goals, and that syndicalist hegemony accounts for the relatively slow growth of the French labor movement as a whole.

baseline: According to him, leaders were very influential in the drafting of syndicalist ideas.

baseline: He also sees Marxist ideas reflected in the movement, as leading syndicalists, such as Ferdinand Domela Nieuwenhuis and Christiaan Cornelissen, and much of the Australian syndicalist movement were influenced by them, as well as older socialist notions.

baseline: Bill Haywood, an American syndicalist and leading figure in the IWW, defined the union's purpose at the First Convention of the Industrial Workers of the World as "the emancipation of the working class from the slave bondage of capitalism".

baseline: Tom Mann, a British syndicalist, declared that "the object of the unions is to wage the Class War".

baseline: According to syndicalist doctrine, this war was aimed not just at gaining concessions such as higher wages or a shorter working day but at the revolutionary overthrow of capitalism.

baseline: Nevertheless, a number of leading syndicalist figures worked in political parties and some ran for elected office.

baseline: According to Thomas Hagerty, a Catholic priest and IWW leader, "dropping pieces of paper into a hole in a box never did achieve emancipation for the working class, and to my thinking it will never achieve it." Syndicalist trade unions declared their political neutrality and autonomy from political parties.

baseline: The French syndicalist Pouget explained: "The CGT embraces –  outside of all the schools of politics –  all workers cognisant of the struggle to be waged for the elimination of wage-slavery and the employer class." In practice, this neutrality was more ambiguous.

baseline: In the syndicalist conception, unions played a dual role.

prompts: Similarly , syndicalist unions did not work to build large
baseline: Similarly, syndicalist unions did not work to build large strike funds, for fear that they would create bureaucracy separate from the rank-and-file and instill in workers the expectation that the union rather than they would wage the class struggle.

prompts: Thus , " the IWW 's masculine identity incorporated features of working
baseline: Thus, "the IWW's masculine identity incorporated features of working-class solidarity and protest ... through 'virile' syndicalism." For example, while defending a black fellow worker against a racist insult, an IWW organizer in Louisiana insisted that "he is a man, a union man, an IWW—a MAN! ... and he has proven it by his action." During World War I, one of the IWW's anti-war slogans was "Don't Be a Soldier! Be a Man!" In some cases, syndicalist attitudes towards women changed.

baseline: According to the historian Sharif Gemie, the male orientation of parts of the syndicalist labor movement reflected the ideas of the anarchist Pierre-Joseph Proudhon, who defended patriarchy because women, of their own accord, are "chained to nature".

baseline: In 1912, during the Mexican Revolution of 1910–1920, anarchists formed the syndicalist union House of the World Worker (Casa del Obrero Mundial).

baseline: The syndicalist union confederation USI was formed in 1912 by veterans of both strike movements.

baseline: Both the Dutch NAS and the British ISEL attempted to remedy the lack of a syndicalist counterpart to ISNTUC in 1913, simultaneously publishing calls for an international syndicalist congress in 1913.

baseline: The First International Syndicalist Congress was held in London from 27 September to 2 October.

baseline: Discussions were contentious and did not lead to the founding of a syndicalist international.

baseline: They also decided to launch an International Syndicalist Information Bureau and to hold another congress in Amsterdam.

baseline: Moreover, a number of anarchists led by Peter Kropotkin, including the influential syndicalist Christiaan Cornelissen, issued the Manifesto of the Sixteen, supporting the Allied cause in the war.

baseline: As a result, according to historians like Darlington or van der Linden and Thorpe, the CGT was no longer a revolutionary syndicalist organization after the start of World War I.

baseline: From the start of the war, even before Italy did so, a minority within USI, led by the most famous Italian syndicalist, Alceste De Ambris, called on the Italian state to take the Allies' side.

baseline: August 1914 edition of Die Einigkeit, a German syndicalist newspaper, protesting the outbreak of war

baseline: Although the congress was poorly planned and prohibited by the Spanish authorities, delegates managed to discuss resistance to the war and extending international cooperation between syndicalist groups.

baseline: German, Swedish, Dutch, and Spanish syndicalists denounced nationalism with Tierra y Libertad, a syndicalist journal in Barcelona, calling it a "grotesque mentality".

baseline: Thanks in part to their fidelity to internationalism, syndicalist organizations profited from this development and expanded as the war drew to an end.

baseline: Russian syndicalists organized around the journal Golos Truda (The Voice of Labor), which had a circulation of around 25,000, and the Union of Anarcho-Syndicalist Propaganda.

baseline: The syndicalists viewed the factory committees as the true form of syndicalist organization, not unions.

baseline: The Petrograd Soviet established the 66-member Petrograd Military Revolutionary Committee, which included four anarchists, among them the syndicalist Shatov.

baseline: The government reacted by having anarchists throughout the country arrested, including a number of syndicalist leaders.

baseline: Augustin Souchy, a German anarcho-syndicalist, hailed it "the great passion that swept us all along.

baseline: The syndicalist FVdG, which had just 6,000 members before the war and was almost completely suppressed by the state during the war, regrouped at a conference in Berlin in December 1918.

prompts: The 1918 Portugal general strike was called for November but
baseline: The 1918 Portugal general strike was called for November but failed, and in 1919 the syndicalist General Confederation of Labour (Confederação Geral do Trabalho, CGT) was formed as the country's first national union confederation.

prompts: In Argentina , FORA had split into the anarcho
baseline: In Argentina, FORA had split into the anarcho-communist FORA V and the syndicalist FORA IX.

prompts: They formed the Revolutionary Syndicalist Committees and attempted to push the
baseline: They formed the Revolutionary Syndicalist Committees and attempted to push the CGT as a whole to support the Comintern.

baseline: Instead, the congress revealed the irreconcilable differences between the syndicalist and the Bolshevik approach.

baseline: A document proposed by Solomon Lozovsky derided the apolitical unions as "lackeys of imperialist capitalism" for their betrayal during the war, to which syndicalists replied that of the syndicalist unions this only applied to the CGT.

prompts: From the early 1920s , the traditional syndicalist movements in most countries began to wane ;
baseline: From the early 1920s, the traditional syndicalist movements in most countries began to wane; state repression played a role, although movements that were not suppressed also declined.

prompts: According to van der Linden and Thorpe , syndicalist organizations saw themselves as having
baseline: According to van der Linden and Thorpe, syndicalist organizations saw themselves as having three options: they could stay true to their revolutionary principles and be marginalized, they could give up those principles in order to adapt to new conditions, or they could disband or merge into non-syndicalist organizations.

prompts: The Spanish Revolution of 1936 resulted in the widespread
baseline: The Spanish Revolution of 1936 resulted in the widespread implementation of anarcho-syndicalist and more broadly socialist organizational principles throughout various portions of the country for two to three years, primarily Catalonia, Aragon, Andalusia, and parts of the Levante, with the main union organization of the Republican faction being the CNT.

prompts: By the end of the 1930s , meaningful legal syndicalist organizations existed only in Bolivia
baseline: By the end of the 1930s, meaningful legal syndicalist organizations existed only in Bolivia, Chile, Sweden and Uruguay.

baseline: In Russia, Italy, Portugal, Germany, Spain, and the Netherlands, syndicalist movements were suppressed by authoritarian governments.

prompts: Bolshevism 's overcoming of these limitations and its success in Russia drew syndicalist leaders and
baseline: Bolshevism's overcoming of these limitations and its success in Russia drew syndicalist leaders and members.

prompts: It also exacerbated splits within the
baseline: It also exacerbated splits within the syndicalist camp.

baseline: During the 1980s in the Polish People's Republic, the trade union Solidarity (Solidarność), even though not strictly syndicalist, attracted masses of dissident workers by reviving many syndicalist ideas and practices.

prompts: Among its member organizations is the British Solidarity Federation , which was formed in 1950 ,
baseline: Among its member organizations is the British Solidarity Federation, which was formed in 1950, originally named the Syndicalist Workers' Federation.
